user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
```c
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I reviewed the provided code and related definitions for constructs that would be compiler-specific language extensions (examples: GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __attribute__((...)), __extension__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, asm, nonstandard keywords, vendor-specific storage-class specifiers, named address-space qualifiers, or other documented compiler extensions). None of those appear in the code. The items that could be mistaken for extensions are standard C features: - ((osal_id_t){0}) is a C99 compound literal (standard, not a compiler extension). - static inline is the standard inline usage. - bool and stdbool-style usage is standard C99. - The macros (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED) and the inline helper OS_ObjectIndexFromToken are plain preprocessor and inline function constructs, not compiler extensions. - The forward declaration typedef and pointer/array indexing are standard C. Therefore there are no occurrences of documented compiler-specific language extensions in the provided fragments, so nothing needs to be flagged for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 investigation.
